metadata.subject: Breaking Down Democracy: Goals, Strategies, and Methods of Modern Authoritarians

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability

financial_information.description: Russian loan to Hungary for Paks nuclear power plant expansion
Loan from Russian bank to France's National Front
Bahrain spending on U.S. and UK political consultants (2011-2015)
Annual value of Egyptian intelligence agency contract with U.S. PR firms
Payment to Michael Flynn's consulting firm by Turkish-linked company

key_quotes: 'If we want to organize our national state to replace the liberal state, it is very important that we make it clear that we are not opposing nongovernmental organizations here, and it is not nongovernmental organizations who are moving against us, but paid political activists who are attempting to enforce foreign interests here in Hungary.' - Viktor Orbán
'As an operator, but not as a human being, I would say Putin. The way he played the whole Syria thing. Brilliant.' - Nigel Farage

'I admire his cool head. Because there is a cold war being waged against him by the EU at the behest of the United States... I admire that he has managed to restore pride and contentment to a great nation that had been humiliated and persecuted for 70 years.' - Marine Le Pen
'He makes a decision and he executes it, quickly. And then everybody reacts. That's what you call a leader.' - Rudy Giuliani
legal_issues: Political prisoners in Azerbaijan, Venezuela, China, Egypt
Decriminalization of domestic violence in Russia
blackmail_coercion_indicators: Russian energy cutoffs to neighboring countries
Cyber attacks on Estonia and Ukraine
Passport distribution in breakaway regions to justify intervention
analysis.summary: This comprehensive report by Freedom House analyzes the methods and strategies employed by modern authoritarian regimes (particularly Russia, China, Hungary, Turkey, Venezuela, and Azerbaijan) to undermine democracy globally. It details how these regimes use sophisticated techniques including propaganda, political interference, economic pressure, legal manipulation, and coercion to maintain power and influence both domestically and internationally. The report highlights concerning trends such as the return of political prisoners, revival of forced confessions, erosion of media freedom, and increased foreign aggression. It also examines how authoritarian governments cultivate relationships with sympathetic political movements in democracies and hire Western lobbyists to burnish their images. The document concludes with recommendations for various sectors to counter these authoritarian threats.
recommendations: Appoint a director of global communications to counter authoritarian messaging
Increase media coverage of authoritarian methods and their enablers
Academic community should defend freedom of thought and open inquiry
Businesses should avoid relationships that require violating democratic principles
EU should review member states' democratic institutions and develop new sanctions
Private foundations should support democracy efforts as governments waver
Politicians should call out colleagues who admire authoritarian figures
Human rights organizations should focus more on political prisoners
Support civil society in authoritarian environments
